awd_titl_txt: iBiology: A Video Resource for the International Life Science Community
awd_abstract_narration:
iBiology is a web-based video collection for the life sciences community, which provides a window into the process of scientific discovery. iBiology's mission is to make recorded scientific talks by the world's leading biologists available on-demand and free-of-charge. iBiology's primary audience ranges from undergraduates to professional scientists, although iBiology's resources are also being used by high school students. In this project, iBiology will expand its offerings to produce 40 life sciences research talks per year, run a competition for young scientists to receive training and record their own iBiology talk, and produce a new series covering research techniques. A "flipped" course for use by educators will be produced each year. iBiology provides high schools, community colleges, and liberal arts colleges with access to high-level biology learning resources, thereby helping their faculty both to learn themselves and to teach their students. iBiology actively seeks to engage diverse national and international communities in the exciting future of biology through outreach and volunteer activities.

In this project iBiology will produce the following resources: iBioSeminars (research talks given by leading scientists); Discovery talks (short talks that cover famous discoveries); a Technique Series; "Flipped Courses" (courses will be produced on subjects where there is a need and the content is not found online or commonly taught in universities) and other Education Resources (activities or materials to accompany videos); and The Young Scientist Series (a competition highlighting work from talented young graduate students and postdoctoral fellows).

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this grant was to tell the stories of science to scientists, students, and the public, through the power of video communication. The course of this work spanned a global pandemic which upended travel and in-person video recording. It also accelerated what had already been a rapid transformation in video recording and delivery technologies and personal viewing habits. Consequently, the work in this grant had to pivot accordingly.

The grant started out continuing a long-standing approach to iBiology's video production by making recorded lectures primarily for a scientific audience. These research talks, often more than one segment long, were given mostly by senior scientists in a studio with a greenscreen backdrop that allowed for a speaker's slides to be added post production. The large body of research talks that we produced during this grant period provided open access, trusted content on different aspects of life science research, including discoveries and technique development, for the scientific community.

The in-person productions of recording in a studio were no longer possible in the wake of COVID-19, and so iBiology switched to remote recordings and reimagining the output of videos to take a more cinematic storytelling approach. We also expanded our focus to produce content for educational audiences and the public. Instead of talks prepared by researchers, the iBiology staff crafted short film narratives using high-quality cinematography, animations and graphics, and rounds of iterative video editing. The resulting work is shorter in duration and more highly produced and accessible to broader audiences for greater impact.

With a renewed focus on education, specifically, we started testing some of our short films and videos in a large introductory undergraduate biology class at a minority-serving institution. We also had one-on-one focus groups with undergraduate educators. In an increasingly video-driven hybrid world of academic instruction, considering how to best integrate short science films is of special urgent importance. Through these collective efforts, we learned that iBiology provides high quality, trusted supplemental content that explains complicated concepts clearly, gives insights into how the scientific process works, and also engages younger, more diverse students in science.  

We also worked on novel ways to distribute some of the more accessible short films to the public. We used our sizable newsletter, social media, and digital video distribution platforms. We also piloted both online webinar-driven discussion panels and in-person screenings combined with panel discussions. Through these platforms and events, we observed how our cinematic, thought-provoking films can engage the public on important science topics, even inspiring curiosity and wonder.

In addition to expanding our impact to educational audiences and the public, this change in approach to video production created a new paradigm for collaborative storytelling between the iBiology staff (who are largely PhD-trained scientists) and the numerous professional filmmakers who were brought into the process. The creative process of scientists and storytellers coming together, led to new insights into how to make high-quality science films. The scientists learned about filmmaking and the filmmakers learned about science. 

Finally, going beyond our video and film productions, we were able to continue our science communication training program for diverse, early-career scientists through the support of this grant. Called "Share Your Research", we provided excellent in person training sessions (years 2016-2019), as well as remote training sessions (2020-2022), to 4-8 scientists per year. These sessions were an excellent professional development opportunity that improved participants' scientific presentation as well as general communication skills, which are a key competency for any science or science-related career.
